text: I try to spend a couple of hours an eve learning something new. Generally in the form of podcasts, books or audiobooks, and courses. There are a couple of days a week where I don’t focus on building my skills or learning something new. I like feeling as though I’m continually engaging my mind and growing my skills - it’s fun, rather than a slog - and I think part of that is about finding “teachers” and authors who you connect with and enjoy learning from.

text:
Ultimately, the goal for most people is to drive conversions with content. So, I’d look for:
• Customer-Content Fit
• Topically Relevant Posts that generate links (original research, stats page, etc)
• Internal links from 
I’ll explain...

“Customer-content fit" Is the idea of catering content to a specific person rather than a topic and a surprising number of companies miss this mark.

For example, if you sell a SaaS product to mainly VPs of sales, writing a post about "5 Tactics to Improve Black Friday Sales" probably won't earn a VP’s attention as it’s too tactical whereas VPs deal with more strategy (hiring, etc). 

As most people do purely keyword research, it’s common for the content to become topical (sales) rather than specific to a persona (VP of Sales).

Once you have customer-content fit, you need enough links that the post can rank well. Therefore, I’d look to see if they have any original research posts or even a stats page with a lot of links. This piece should be topically relevant though not necessarily persona relevant as the goal is to drive topically relevant links- not sales. 

From there, I’d see if they internally link from those highly linked-to pages to generate a lot of links and then internally link from that post to the blog posts. 

Unless your goal is purely brand awareness, I’d recommend avoiding traffic as a metric. This will drive a lot of irrelevant users to your website, which is fine, but it doesn’t help your bottom line.

text: anyone else enjoy co-branded content for PR? I'm a big fan, when there's a fit and especially when it leverages data from both brands to tell an interesting story that neither brand could tell on its own. Feel free to DM me, especially if you're in the B2C space, if you ever want to kick around ideas for ways to collaborate + share some wins.

text:
Have another question for the amazing folks in this group — there’s a lot of talk about content distribution (and rightfully so.) I’m looking for some examples of companies have a great internal process for getting their team / employees to share content.

Maybe it’s a internal newsletter with everything the company has published.
Or a slack channel specifically for sharing.

Anyone companies that do this really well?

I'm open to hearing more :ear:

text: We just brought on a sales enablement platform (Seismic) to help us surface content for sales reps throughout the sales process. While there are lots of features we're excited about, the one that addresses this problem is that it has integrations with Salesforce and Salesloft so we can tag content based on sales stage, persona, etc. and it will appear in the platforms our team members are already using rather than having them learn new systems. We've just started the onboarding process so can't speak yet to how successful this is, but we're excited to see the results!

text: I’m documenting (and trying to find efficiencies in) our content processes right now, so I’m curious: how many weeks, from kickoff to design completion, does it take you/your team to produce a downloadable asset (say a 20 page ebook/guide kinda thing)? Bonus points for anyone who think they has a killer repeatable process that works for writers and stakeholders who’d like to walk me thru it!

text:
<@U01HEQWRG0G> we just brought on Newscred for the same reason, only to find that we misunderstood and did not buy the upgrade necessary for the salesforce integration. le sigh. LOL. I used Seismic at a previous company though, and it improved things for them a lot!

<@U013W71AUMT> we have a slack channel where we share content to be promoted, and we just naturally have pretty involved employees on social. If it’s something we’re hoping people will share more than usual, someone will create suggested post copy and maybe some graphics to share, just to make it super simple and keep stuff on message.

text: 2 months is usually a fair amount of wiggle room for research, drafting, layout, revisions. The variable is ALWAYs feedback rounds getting lost in chaos. I usually "lock" feedback rounds for internal feedback to 72 hour windows.

elements.text: 2 months is usually a fair amount of wiggle room for research, drafting, layout, revisions. The variable is ALWAYs feedback rounds getting lost in chaos. I usually "lock" feedback rounds for internal feedback to 72 hour windows.

text: Yeah, we’re at like twice that now. At least. One of our biggest problems is legal review, but feedback rounds are of course a big one also. Have you had to play hardball to get them to believe you that you’ll lock it? I find that people just keep providing feedback and it doesn’t really matter if they’re too late.

text: Similar timeline here, too—6-8 weeks is about our standard timeline for creating a brand new long-form piece of content. Often though, we'll create long-form pieces based off of a blog, podcast, or webinar series so lots of the copy is already produced, and the heavy lifting is just repackaging that content in ebook form and giving it a place to live on our website, in our sales cadences, etc. :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
I launched and run an employee advocacy program  (~200 monthly active members) at my previous company. It was huge with sales.

Gamification is key to maintain everyone engaged. Using a tool is the best but they are not cheap, I was using GaggleAMP, the UI was pretty outdated but it allowed to easily share content and the price was :ok_hand:
